results.name: a(1) = 1; for n > 1, a(n) is the smallest positive integer not already used such that a(n)*a(n-1) + 1 is a perfect square.
comment: Does this sequence contain every positive integer? We could get an equally interesting sequence by choosing a(1) to be any other positive integer.
A sequence with the same condition but without the requirement for a(n) to be distinct would end up repeating (1,3) or (2,4), depending on the initial term. - _Ivan Neretin_, May 26 2015
link: Ivan Neretin, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
example: 10 is followed by 36 because 10*36+1 = 19^2 and 8 and 12 were already used.
